Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Bench-Top Flow Cytometer for Multi-Disciplinary Research and Education at Seton Hall University
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to Seton Hall University to purchase the bench-top flow cytometer, Miltenyi MACSQuant Analyzer. This instrument will advance bio-related education in two different science departments (the Department of Biological Sciences and the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry) and the Institute of NeuroImmune Pharmacology at Seton Hall University. This equipment will enhance our teaching collaborations, and will promote multi-disciplinary research, including, but not limited to: cell biology, molecular biology, microbiology, immunology, developmental biology, neuroscience and biochemistry. The flow cytometer enables us to analyze various cell populations in a single sample and assess multiple molecules on the cell surface and/or inside cells simultaneously. It facilitates the analyses of protein, DNA, RNA or small biomolecules concurrently. This state-of-the-art technology will provide essential information to advance our research, deliver a positive intellectual impact on education, and nurture future scientists.

This instrument will be used in various activities aimed at broader impacts: 1) Hands-on laboratory training for undergraduate and graduate students; 2) Training of underrepresented students; 3) Training of women scientists; 4) Training of local high school students and teachers; 5) As part of our community out-reach programs in workshop and scientific events where alumni, parents and visitors will have the opportunity to learn of the versatility of its use. Overall, the flow cytometer will be a great asset for the department, for it will fulfill our mission to train students in scientific principles and technologies preparing them for future professional contributions to society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The flow cytometer produces positive and broad impacts on the multi-disciplinary research (two departments and one institute), including, but not limited to: cell biology, molecular biology, microbiology, immunology, developmental biology, neuroscience and biochemistry. This awarded flow cytometer allows us to analyze different cell populations in a sample, to simultaneously measure the up- or down-regulation of various protein, DNA and RNA expression reflecting the change of cell status, and to assess various cellular responses upon stimuli in an efficient and cost-effective manner.  Results obtained from this instrument provided informative and valuable insights, which resulted in many publications of peer-reviewed papers, various scientific meeting presentations, and grant applications, etc. These results therefore advance the knowledge, and deliver positive intellectual impacts on education and nurtures future scientists. The instrumentation is also used in activities aimed at broader impacts. 1) Hands-on laboratory training. SHU is largely an undergraduate institution. In addition to graduate students, undergraduates receive laboratory training and obtain experience in analyzing data and solve complicated scientific problems. 2) Training underrepresented students. SHU has a high percentage (25-45% among majors) of under-represented students. Broadening the participation of this group in science and technology is a logical and practical step. 3) Training women scientists. Both departments participate in the Clare Boothe Luce Scholar training, which focuses on recruitment, retention and training of undergraduate women in STEM fields. 4) Training local high school students and teachers. Both departments participate in the Project SEED and North Star program which brings high school students to SHU for research. Additionally, the summer workshop broads the training for more high school students and teachers. 5) Community out-reaches. The flow cytometer and associated research programs is also used as a part of SHU’s contribution to local/regional scientific and open house events. Thus, alumni, parents and visitors have the opportunity to learn of the impacts of this instrument. Overall, the flow cytometer is a great asset for the mission of training students in scientific principles and technologies for the greater good of society.
